ost_step.2: Using quadratic equation \( ax^{2}+bx+c=(x-\alpha)(x-\beta)\), let’s determine \(\alpha\) & \(\beta\). \[\Rightarrow -\left(\dfrac{-8}{\frac{dF}{da}}\right)^{1/2}=-\sqrt{4}\Rightarrow x=-2,\pm2\]

direct_answer.text: Firstly, based on hint provided it states 'notice', therefore directly comparing first three parts of problem statement reveals value equality condition i.e., average (\[average =\text {Sum over N items } /N \] thus [Cubic Sum]/N=[square sum ]*\lambda*N ) Thus , cube summation being double square multiplication implies lambda (ratio constant here) equalling 2.[Since All Terms Equal X Hence Lambda Can Also Be Derived]) Now re-calculate Sqrtsure [\[If Factorized Form Is Given As Ax²+BX+\Phi Where B&Delta Have Common Roots => RHS -Left Hand Side Will Give You Delta Coefficient Of Cubic Formula Which Further Leads To Value For Root Based On It And Other Constants Present]] ; From Quadratic : \\[-1pt]\\ \[\Rightarrow -\left(\dfrac{-8}{\frac{dF}{da}}\right)=\left(\dfrac {-8}{\frac{d}{(sa)}\Bigg)} .\, \,     &=   [-8]*[{Sa}/{[f d/(Na)]}]    =~[-8*{s*(xa)/[ f * ((delta)}{na})]}

0.user_question:
Let $(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, such that
\[\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i = 96, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 144, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^3 = 216.\]Find the sum of all possible values of $n.$

1.subquestion: Use Vieta's formulas to relate the roots (or sums/products) of three cubic polynomials to their coefficients. Here I am not asking you how those formulas work or where they come from; just assume them as facts. In particular, recall here only that if $\{r_1,\dots, r_k\}$ be the set of complex solutions to some polynomial $p(x)=c_nx^n+c_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdots+ c_0=0,$ then $$r_1+\cdots+r_k=-c_{n-1}/c_n$$

subanswer.text: Using Vieta's formulae we have \[\begin{aligned}-a_1 &= -\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_1}, \\-(a_2)&=--\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_2},\\&\vdots \\ -(a_n)&=--\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_n}.\end{aligned}\] So now solving above equations using elimination method we observe following relation $$\frac{-a_1}{a_1}+ \frac{-a_2}{a_2} +\cdots + \frac{-a_n}{a_n}= n.$$ Hence required solution would simply satisfy below linear combination which clearly implies summation over natural no. therefore our final ans should be equal to infinity because its infinite choices so hence S=infinite . 0.user_question:
Let $(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, such that
\[\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i = 96, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 144, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^3 = 216.\]Find the sum of all possible values of $n.$

direct_answer.text:
We know that \[\left(\sum_{i=1}^n a_i\right)^2 \ge \sum_{i=1}^n a_i^2,\]with equality when $\{a_i\}$ forms a geometric progression (GP.) Similarly, since \[[S(n)]^2 - S(n+1)^2 = [S''(n)+ns'(n)]/2\]where \(S\) denotes summation notation and \(S'', n'\), etc., denote derivatives evaluated at \(n\). Equality holds precisely when \(\{a_i\}\text{ {is} }\text{ {an arithmetic progression}} .\) Thus we may assume without loss of generality (\"OUGHT\" abbreviation!) that our set consists entirely of distinct integers; otherwise it would admit no GP. Because squares add up nicely but cubes do not generally form sums easily, let us try some small triangular square sets first, starting with those whose largest value occurs last:\[(6,4,3),(6,4,2),(6,4,1),$$
$(7,3,2),\qquad(8,2,1)\].\]From here things get tricky unless I am missing something obvious

0.user_question:
Let $(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, such that
\[\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i = 96, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 144, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^3 = 216.\]Find the sum of all possible values of $n.$

direct_answer.text:
We know that \[\left(\sum_{i=1}^n a_i\right)^2 \ge \sum_{i=1}^n a_i^2,\]with equality when $\{a_i\}$ forms a geometric progression (GP.) Similarly, since \[[S(n)]^2 - S(n+1)^2 = [S''(n)+ns'(n)]/2\]where \(S\) denotes summation notation and \(S'', n'\), etc., denote derivatives evaluated at \(n\). Equality holds precisely when \(\{a_i\}\text{ {is} }\text{ {an arithmetic progression}} .\) Thus we may assume without loss of generality (\"OUGHT\" abbreviation!) that our set consists entirely of distinct integers; otherwise it would admit no GP. Because squares add up nicely but cubes do not generally form sums easily, let us try some small triangular square sets first, starting with those whose largest value occurs last:\[(6,4,3),(6,4,2),(6,4,1),$$
$(7,3,2),\qquad(8,2,1)\].\]From here things get tricky unless I am missing something obvious

0.user_question:
Let $(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, such that
\[\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i = 96, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 144, \quad \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^3 = 216.\]Find the sum of all possible values of $n.$

1.subquestion: Use Vieta's formulas to relate the roots (or sums/products) of three cubic polynomials to their coefficients. Here I am not asking you how those formulas work or where they come from; just assume them as facts. In particular, recall here only that if $\{r_1,\dots, r_k\}$ be the set of complex solutions to some polynomial $p(x)=c_nx^n+c_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdots+ c_0=0,$ then $$r_1+\cdots+r_k=-c_{n-1}/c_n$$

subanswer.text: Using Vieta's formulae we have \[\begin{aligned}-a_1 &= -\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_1}, \\-(a_2)&=--\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_2},\\&\vdots \\ -(a_n)&=--\frac{(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_n)}{na_n}.\end{aligned}\] So now solving above equations using elimination method we observe following relation $$\frac{-a_1}{a_1}+ \frac{-a_2}{a_2} +\cdots + \frac{-a_n}{a_n}= n.$$ Hence required solution would simply satisfy below linear combination which clearly implies summation over natural no. therefore our final ans should be equal to infinity because its infinite choices so hence S=infinite .
